You said:
I use glfw, opengl with glew, std_image for teture, how do I structure/abstract my project???
ChatGPT said:

When structuring an OpenGL project using GLFW, GLEW, and stb_image, it's essential to follow a modular and maintainable design. Below is a well-structured approach to abstracting your project.

1. Organize Your Files

Separate your project into logical folders:

bash
/MyOpenGLProject
│── /src
│   ├── main.cpp
│   ├── /core
│   │   ├── Window.h/.cpp        # GLFW window abstraction
│   │   ├── Shader.h/.cpp        # Shader management
│   │   ├── Texture.h/.cpp       # Texture handling
│   │   ├── Mesh.h/.cpp          # Mesh handling
│   │   ├── Renderer.h/.cpp      # OpenGL draw calls
│   │   ├── Camera.h/.cpp        # Camera abstraction
│   │   ├── Input.h/.cpp         # Input handling
│   │   ├── Timer.h/.cpp         # Delta time management
│   │   ├── Debug.h/.cpp         # OpenGL debugging tools
│── /shaders
│   ├── vertex_shader.glsl
│   ├── fragment_shader.glsl
│── /textures
│   ├── texture.png
│── /models
│   ├── cube.obj
│── /vendor                  # External libraries (GLFW, GLEW, stb_image)
│── /build                   # Compiled binaries
│── CMakeLists.txt            # If using CMake
│── Makefile                  # If using Make

2. Core Abstractions

Below are the key classes you need:

2.1 Window Abstraction (GLFW)

Create a Window class to initialize and manage the GLFW window.

cpp
// Window.h
#pragma once
#include <GLFW/glfw3.h>

class Window {
public:
    Window(int width, int height, const char* title);
    ~Window();
    
    bool shouldClose();
    void pollEvents();
    void swapBuffers();

    GLFWwindow* getGLFWwindow() const { return m_Window; }

private:
    GLFWwindow* m_Window;
};

// Window.cpp
#include "Window.h"

Window::Window(int width, int height, const char* title) {
    if (!glfwInit()) {
        throw std::runtime_error("Failed to initialize GLFW!");
    }

    m_Window = glfwCreateWindow(width, height, title, nullptr, nullptr);
    if (!m_Window) {
        glfwTerminate();
        throw std::runtime_error("Failed to create GLFW window!");
    }

    glfwMakeContextCurrent(m_Window);
}

Window::~Window() {
    glfwDestroyWindow(m_Window);
    glfwTerminate();
}

bool Window::shouldClose() { return glfwWindowShouldClose(m_Window); }
void Window::pollEvents() { glfwPollEvents(); }
void Window::swapBuffers() { glfwSwapBuffers(m_Window); }

2.2 Shader Abstraction

Managing shader compilation and linking.

cpp
// Shader.h
#pragma once
#include <string>
#include <GL/glew.h>

class Shader {
public:
    Shader(const std::string& vertexPath, const std::string& fragmentPath);
    ~Shader();

    void use();
    void setUniform(const std::string& name, float value);
    void setUniform(const std::string& name, int value);

private:
    GLuint m_Program;
};

// Shader.cpp
#include "Shader.h"
#include <fstream>
#include <sstream>
#include <iostream>

Shader::Shader(const std::string& vertexPath, const std::string& fragmentPath) {
    // Read shader source code
    std::ifstream vShaderFile(vertexPath);
    std::ifstream fShaderFile(fragmentPath);

    std::stringstream vShaderStream, fShaderStream;
    vShaderStream << vShaderFile.rdbuf();
    fShaderStream << fShaderFile.rdbuf();

    std::string vertexCode = vShaderStream.str();
    std::string fragmentCode = fShaderStream.str();

    const char* vShaderCode = vertexCode.c_str();
    const char* fShaderCode = fragmentCode.c_str();

    // Compile shaders
    GLuint vertex, fragment;
    vertex = glCreateShader(GL_VERTEX_SHADER);
    glShaderSource(vertex, 1, &vShaderCode, NULL);
    glCompileShader(vertex);

    fragment = glCreateShader(GL_FRAGMENT_SHADER);
    glShaderSource(fragment, 1, &fShaderCode, NULL);
    glCompileShader(fragment);

    // Shader Program
    m_Program = glCreateProgram();
    glAttachShader(m_Program, vertex);
    glAttachShader(m_Program, fragment);
    glLinkProgram(m_Program);

    glDeleteShader(vertex);
    glDeleteShader(fragment);
}

Shader::~Shader() {
    glDeleteProgram(m_Program);
}

void Shader::use() { glUseProgram(m_Program); }

2.3 Texture Abstraction (stb_image)

Handles texture loading and binding.

cpp
// Texture.h
#pragma once
#include <GL/glew.h>
#include <string>

class Texture {
public:
    Texture(const std::string& path);
    ~Texture();

    void bind();
    void unbind();

private:
    GLuint m_ID;
};

// Texture.cpp
#include "Texture.h"
#define STB_IMAGE_IMPLEMENTATION
#include "stb_image.h"

Texture::Texture(const std::string& path) {
    glGenTextures(1, &m_ID);
    glBindTexture(GL_TEXTURE_2D, m_ID);

    int width, height, nrChannels;
    unsigned char* data = stbi_load(path.c_str(), &width, &height, &nrChannels, 0);
    if (data) {
        glTexImage2D(GL_TEXTURE_2D, 0, GL_RGB, width, height, 0, GL_RGB, GL_UNSIGNED_BYTE, data);
        glGenerateMipmap(GL_TEXTURE_2D);
    }
    stbi_image_free(data);
}

Texture::~Texture() {
    glDeleteTextures(1, &m_ID);
}

void Texture::bind() { glBindTexture(GL_TEXTURE_2D, m_ID); }
void Texture::unbind() { glBindTexture(GL_TEXTURE_2D, 0); }

2.4 Renderer

Handles rendering.

cpp
// Renderer.h
#pragma once
#include <GL/glew.h>

class Renderer {
public:
    void clear();
    void draw();
};

// Renderer.cpp
#include "Renderer.h"

void Renderer::clear() {
    glClear(GL_COLOR_BUFFER_BIT | GL_DEPTH_BUFFER_BIT);
}

void Renderer::draw() {
    glDrawArrays(GL_TRIANGLES, 0, 36);
}

3. Main Application

Tie everything together in main.cpp.

cpp
#include "Window.h"
#include "Shader.h"
#include "Texture.h"
#include "Renderer.h"

int main() {
    Window window(800, 600, "OpenGL App");

    glewInit();

    Shader shader("shaders/vertex_shader.glsl", "shaders/fragment_shader.glsl");
    Texture texture("textures/texture.png");
    Renderer renderer;

    while (!window.shouldClose()) {
        renderer.clear();

        shader.use();
        texture.bind();

        renderer.draw();

        window.swapBuffers();
        window.pollEvents();
    }

    return 0;
}

4. Additional Considerations

  • Use CMake to manage dependencies.
  • Implement a logging system for debugging.
  • Use an ECS (Entity Component System) if you plan to handle complex scenes.

Conclusion

This structure keeps your code clean, modular, and extendable. By abstracting different OpenGL functionalities into separate classes, you make the codebase easier to maintain and expand. 🚀

You said:
how do handle events in this..........
ChatGPT said:

Handling events (like keyboard and mouse input) in your GLFW & OpenGL project requires integrating an event-driven system. Since GLFW provides callback-based input handling, you can structure event handling efficiently using a dedicated Input class.

1. Basic Input Handling Using Callbacks

GLFW provides built-in functions to capture:

  • Keyboard events (glfwSetKeyCallback)
  • Mouse movement (glfwSetCursorPosCallback)
  • Mouse clicks (glfwSetMouseButtonCallback)
  • Scroll input (glfwSetScrollCallback)

Creating an Input Manager

Define an Input class to manage user interactions.

cpp
// Input.h
#pragma once
#include <GLFW/glfw3.h>

class Input {
public:
    static bool isKeyPressed(int key);
    static bool isMouseButtonPressed(int button);
    static void getMousePosition(double& x, double& y);

    static void setWindow(GLFWwindow* window);
    static void keyCallback(GLFWwindow* window, int key, int scancode, int action, int mods);
    static void mouseButtonCallback(GLFWwindow* window, int button, int action, int mods);
    static void cursorPositionCallback(GLFWwindow* window, double xpos, double ypos);
    
private:
    static GLFWwindow* s_Window;
    static bool s_Keys[1024];
    static bool s_MouseButtons[8];
    static double s_MouseX, s_MouseY;
};

Implementing Input Callbacks

Now, implement the event handlers in Input.cpp.

cpp
// Input.cpp
#include "Input.h"
#include <iostream>

GLFWwindow* Input::s_Window = nullptr;
bool Input::s_Keys[1024] = { false };
bool Input::s_MouseButtons[8] = { false };
double Input::s_MouseX = 0.0;
double Input::s_MouseY = 0.0;

void Input::setWindow(GLFWwindow* window) {
    s_Window = window;
    
    // Set GLFW callbacks
    glfwSetKeyCallback(window, keyCallback);
    glfwSetMouseButtonCallback(window, mouseButtonCallback);
    glfwSetCursorPosCallback(window, cursorPositionCallback);
}

// Key Press Callback
void Input::keyCallback(GLFWwindow* window, int key, int scancode, int action, int mods) {
    if (key >= 0 && key < 1024) {
        if (action == GLFW_PRESS) {
            s_Keys[key] = true;
        } else if (action == GLFW_RELEASE) {
            s_Keys[key] = false;
        }
    }
}

// Mouse Button Callback
void Input::mouseButtonCallback(GLFWwindow* window, int button, int action, int mods) {
    if (button >= 0 && button < 8) {
        if (action == GLFW_PRESS) {
            s_MouseButtons[button] = true;
        } else if (action == GLFW_RELEASE) {
            s_MouseButtons[button] = false;
        }
    }
}

// Cursor Position Callback
void Input::cursorPositionCallback(GLFWwindow* window, double xpos, double ypos) {
    s_MouseX = xpos;
    s_MouseY = ypos;
}

// Check if a key is pressed
bool Input::isKeyPressed(int key) {
    return s_Keys[key];
}

// Check if a mouse button is pressed
bool Input::isMouseButtonPressed(int button) {
    return s_MouseButtons[button];
}

// Get current mouse position
void Input::getMousePosition(double& x, double& y) {
    x = s_MouseX;
    y = s_MouseY;
}

2. Integrating Input Handling in Your Main Loop

Now, modify your main.cpp to use the Input system.

cpp
#include "Window.h"
#include "Shader.h"
#include "Texture.h"
#include "Renderer.h"
#include "Input.h"
#include <iostream>

int main() {
    Window window(800, 600, "OpenGL App");
    glewInit();

    Shader shader("shaders/vertex_shader.glsl", "shaders/fragment_shader.glsl");
    Texture texture("textures/texture.png");
    Renderer renderer;

    Input::setWindow(window.getGLFWwindow());

    while (!window.shouldClose()) {
        renderer.clear();

        // Input Handling
        if (Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_ESCAPE)) {
            glfwSetWindowShouldClose(window.getGLFWwindow(), true);
        }

        double mouseX, mouseY;
        Input::getMousePosition(mouseX, mouseY);
        std::cout << "Mouse Position: (" << mouseX << ", " << mouseY << ")\n";

        shader.use();
        texture.bind();
        renderer.draw();

        window.swapBuffers();
        window.pollEvents();
    }

    return 0;
}

3. Summary

✅ Event-driven system using GLFW callbacks
✅ Encapsulated Input class for easy handling
✅ Supports keyboard, mouse, and cursor input

This design makes handling input clean and modular, so you can easily expand it for camera movement, UI interaction, or game controls. 🚀

You said:
how do I move my camera in this......... for pitch and yaw using mouse
ChatGPT said:

To move your camera using pitch and yaw with the mouse, you need to implement a Camera class that handles:

  • Yaw (Horizontal rotation)
  • Pitch (Vertical rotation)
  • Mouse input for looking around
  • Keyboard input for movement (WASD controls)

1. Create a Camera Class

This class will: ✅ Store position, direction, yaw, and pitch
✅ Process keyboard movement (WASD)
✅ Process mouse input for rotation

cpp
// Camera.h
#pragma once
#include <glm/glm.hpp>
#include <glm/gtc/matrix_transform.hpp>

class Camera {
public:
    Camera(glm::vec3 position, float yaw = -90.0f, float pitch = 0.0f);

    glm::mat4 getViewMatrix();
    void processKeyboard(float deltaTime, bool forward, bool backward, bool left, bool right);
    void processMouse(float offsetX, float offsetY);

    glm::vec3 getPosition() const { return m_Position; }

private:
    glm::vec3 m_Position;
    glm::vec3 m_Front;
    glm::vec3 m_Up;
    glm::vec3 m_Right;
    
    float m_Yaw;
    float m_Pitch;
    float m_Speed;
    float m_Sensitivity;

    void updateCameraVectors();
};

2. Implement Camera Movement

In Camera.cpp, update direction vectors when moving or rotating.

cpp
// Camera.cpp
#include "Camera.h"

Camera::Camera(glm::vec3 position, float yaw, float pitch)
    : m_Position(position), m_Yaw(yaw), m_Pitch(pitch), m_Speed(5.0f), m_Sensitivity(0.1f) {
    updateCameraVectors();
}

// Generate view matrix for OpenGL
glm::mat4 Camera::getViewMatrix() {
    return glm::lookAt(m_Position, m_Position + m_Front, m_Up);
}

// Process keyboard input (WASD)
void Camera::processKeyboard(float deltaTime, bool forward, bool backward, bool left, bool right) {
    float velocity = m_Speed * deltaTime;
    
    if (forward)  m_Position += m_Front * velocity;
    if (backward) m_Position -= m_Front * velocity;
    if (left)     m_Position -= m_Right * velocity;
    if (right)    m_Position += m_Right * velocity;
}

// Process mouse movement (look around)
void Camera::processMouse(float offsetX, float offsetY) {
    offsetX *= m_Sensitivity;
    offsetY *= m_Sensitivity;

    m_Yaw += offsetX;
    m_Pitch += offsetY;

    // Clamp pitch to prevent flipping
    if (m_Pitch > 89.0f)  m_Pitch = 89.0f;
    if (m_Pitch < -89.0f) m_Pitch = -89.0f;

    updateCameraVectors();
}

// Update camera direction vectors
void Camera::updateCameraVectors() {
    glm::vec3 front;
    front.x = cos(glm::radians(m_Yaw)) * cos(glm::radians(m_Pitch));
    front.y = sin(glm::radians(m_Pitch));
    front.z = sin(glm::radians(m_Yaw)) * cos(glm::radians(m_Pitch));

    m_Front = glm::normalize(front);
    m_Right = glm::normalize(glm::cross(m_Front, glm::vec3(0.0f, 1.0f, 0.0f)));
    m_Up = glm::normalize(glm::cross(m_Right, m_Front));
}

3. Update Input System

Modify your Input.h and Input.cpp to track mouse movement.

cpp
// Input.h
#pragma once
#include <GLFW/glfw3.h>

class Input {
public:
    static bool isKeyPressed(int key);
    static void getMouseOffset(float& offsetX, float& offsetY);
    static void setWindow(GLFWwindow* window);
    
    static void keyCallback(GLFWwindow* window, int key, int scancode, int action, int mods);
    static void cursorPositionCallback(GLFWwindow* window, double xpos, double ypos);
    
private:
    static GLFWwindow* s_Window;
    static bool s_Keys[1024];

    static float s_LastX, s_LastY;
    static float s_OffsetX, s_OffsetY;
    static bool s_FirstMouse;
};

cpp
// Input.cpp
#include "Input.h"

GLFWwindow* Input::s_Window = nullptr;
bool Input::s_Keys[1024] = { false };
float Input::s_LastX = 400, Input::s_LastY = 300;
float Input::s_OffsetX = 0.0f, Input::s_OffsetY = 0.0f;
bool Input::s_FirstMouse = true;

void Input::setWindow(GLFWwindow* window) {
    s_Window = window;
    glfwSetKeyCallback(window, keyCallback);
    glfwSetCursorPosCallback(window, cursorPositionCallback);
    glfwSetInputMode(window, GLFW_CURSOR, GLFW_CURSOR_DISABLED);  // Hide cursor
}

void Input::keyCallback(GLFWwindow* window, int key, int scancode, int action, int mods) {
    if (key >= 0 && key < 1024) {
        if (action == GLFW_PRESS) s_Keys[key] = true;
        else if (action == GLFW_RELEASE) s_Keys[key] = false;
    }
}

// Mouse movement callback
void Input::cursorPositionCallback(GLFWwindow* window, double xpos, double ypos) {
    if (s_FirstMouse) {
        s_LastX = xpos;
        s_LastY = ypos;
        s_FirstMouse = false;
    }

    s_OffsetX = xpos - s_LastX;
    s_OffsetY = s_LastY - ypos;  // Reversed because y-coordinates go bottom-up in OpenGL

    s_LastX = xpos;
    s_LastY = ypos;
}

void Input::getMouseOffset(float& offsetX, float& offsetY) {
    offsetX = s_OffsetX;
    offsetY = s_OffsetY;
    s_OffsetX = 0.0f;  // Reset after reading
    s_OffsetY = 0.0f;
}

4. Integrate Camera in Main Loop

Modify main.cpp to use the camera system.

cpp
#include "Window.h"
#include "Shader.h"
#include "Renderer.h"
#include "Input.h"
#include "Camera.h"
#include <glm/gtc/matrix_transform.hpp>

int main() {
    Window window(800, 600, "OpenGL App");
    glewInit();
    Input::setWindow(window.getGLFWwindow());

    Shader shader("shaders/vertex_shader.glsl", "shaders/fragment_shader.glsl");
    Renderer renderer;

    Camera camera(glm::vec3(0.0f, 0.0f, 3.0f));
    float lastFrame = 0.0f;

    while (!window.shouldClose()) {
        float currentFrame = glfwGetTime();
        float deltaTime = currentFrame - lastFrame;
        lastFrame = currentFrame;

        // Handle input
        if (Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_ESCAPE)) {
            glfwSetWindowShouldClose(window.getGLFWwindow(), true);
        }

        bool forward  = Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_W);
        bool backward = Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_S);
        bool left     = Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_A);
        bool right    = Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_D);

        camera.processKeyboard(deltaTime, forward, backward, left, right);

        float offsetX, offsetY;
        Input::getMouseOffset(offsetX, offsetY);
        camera.processMouse(offsetX, offsetY);

        glm::mat4 view = camera.getViewMatrix();
        shader.use();
        shader.setUniform("view", view);

        renderer.clear();
        renderer.draw();

        window.swapBuffers();
        window.pollEvents();
    }

    return 0;
}

5. Summary

✅ WASD movement using processKeyboard()
✅ Mouse look using processMouse()
✅ View matrix updates camera in getViewMatrix()

This lets you freely move and look around like in a first-person camera system. 🚀🎮

You're in great shape! 🎯 But there are a few enhancements and polishing steps to make your camera and project even more robust:

✅ 1. Fix Sudden Mouse Jumps (First-Move Issue)

Currently, the first mouse movement jumps because we instantly subtract from an uninitialized position.

Fix:

  • Set s_LastX and s_LastY to the first recorded cursor position.

Modify this in cursorPositionCallback() (inside Input.cpp):

cpp
void Input::cursorPositionCallback(GLFWwindow* window, double xpos, double ypos) {
    if (s_FirstMouse) {  // Fix sudden jump on first move
        s_LastX = xpos;
        s_LastY = ypos;
        s_FirstMouse = false;
    }

    s_OffsetX = xpos - s_LastX;
    s_OffsetY = s_LastY - ypos;  // Inverted y-axis

    s_LastX = xpos;
    s_LastY = ypos;
}

✅ 2. Enable Diagonal Movement (Smooth Input)

Right now, holding two keys (W+A or W+D) is slower than pressing one key. This happens because movement is calculated in separate if-statements.

Fix: Normalize diagonal movement:
Modify processKeyboard() in Camera.cpp:

cpp
void Camera::processKeyboard(float deltaTime, bool forward, bool backward, bool left, bool right) {
    glm::vec3 direction(0.0f);
    
    if (forward)  direction += m_Front;
    if (backward) direction -= m_Front;
    if (left)     direction -= m_Right;
    if (right)    direction += m_Right;
    
    if (glm::length(direction) > 0) {  
        direction = glm::normalize(direction);  // Fix diagonal movement
        m_Position += direction * m_Speed * deltaTime;
    }
}

✅ 3. Lock Camera Pitch (Prevent Flip)

Right now, pitch flips when looking straight up/down (above 90° or below -90°).

Fix: Clamp m_Pitch properly in processMouse().
Modify:

cpp
if (m_Pitch > 89.0f)  m_Pitch = 89.0f;
if (m_Pitch < -89.0f) m_Pitch = -89.0f;

✅ 4. Make Movement Frame-Independent

Problem: Movement speed depends on FPS.
Fix: Multiply speed by deltaTime. You already have this ✔️ in your processKeyboard(), so you're good!

cpp
float velocity = m_Speed * deltaTime;

✅ 5. Improve Camera Responsiveness (Adjust Sensitivity & Speed)

Right now, sensitivity might be too high or low, depending on your screen DPI.

Solution: Add customizable speed/sensitivity controls in Camera.h:

cpp
void setSpeed(float speed) { m_Speed = speed; }
void setSensitivity(float sensitivity) { m_Sensitivity = sensitivity; }

Then, modify in main.cpp:

cpp
camera.setSpeed(7.0f);
camera.setSensitivity(0.2f);

✅ 6. Pass Projection Matrix to Shader

Right now, you're setting only the view matrix. To properly transform objects in 3D space, you need a projection matrix.

Modify main.cpp:

cpp
glm::mat4 projection = glm::perspective(glm::radians(45.0f), 800.0f / 600.0f, 0.1f, 100.0f);
shader.setUniform("projection", projection);

Then, in your vertex shader (vertex_shader.glsl):

glsl
uniform mat4 view;
uniform mat4 projection;

void main() {
    gl_Position = projection * view * vec4(position, 1.0);
}

✅ 7. Debug Mode (Enable/Disable Mouse Capture)

If you want to toggle mouse capture (e.g., press ESC to show the cursor), modify main.cpp:

cpp
bool mouseCaptured = true;

if (Input::isKeyPressed(GLFW_KEY_ESCAPE)) {
    mouseCaptured = !mouseCaptured;
    glfwSetInputMode(window.getGLFWwindow(), GLFW_CURSOR, 
                     mouseCaptured ? GLFW_CURSOR_DISABLED : GLFW_CURSOR_NORMAL);
}

1️⃣ Lighting System (Directional, Point, and Spotlights)

We'll implement three types of lights: ✅ Directional Light – Like the sun 🌞 (affects all objects equally)
✅ Point Light – Like a lamp 🔥 (light weakens with distance)
✅ Spotlight – Like a flashlight 🔦 (cone-shaped light)

1.1. Modify Vertex Shader

We need to pass normals and light positions to the shader.

glsl
#version 330 core

layout (location = 0) in vec3 aPos;
layout (location = 1) in vec3 aNormal;

uniform mat4 model;
uniform mat4 view;
uniform mat4 projection;

out vec3 FragPos;
out vec3 Normal;

void main() {
    FragPos = vec3(model * vec4(aPos, 1.0));  
    Normal = mat3(transpose(inverse(model))) * aNormal;  

    gl_Position = projection * view * model * vec4(aPos, 1.0);
}

1.2. Modify Fragment Shader

Implement Blinn-Phong Lighting for realistic lighting.

glsl
#version 330 core

struct DirectionalLight {
    vec3 direction;
    vec3 ambient;
    vec3 diffuse;
    vec3 specular;
};

struct PointLight {
    vec3 position;
    vec3 ambient;
    vec3 diffuse;
    vec3 specular;
    float constant;
    float linear;
    float quadratic;
};

struct Spotlight {
    vec3 position;
    vec3 direction;
    float cutOff;
    float outerCutOff;
    
    vec3 ambient;
    vec3 diffuse;
    vec3 specular;
};

uniform DirectionalLight dirLight;
uniform PointLight pointLight;
uniform Spotlight spotLight;

uniform vec3 viewPos;

in vec3 FragPos;
in vec3 Normal;

out vec4 FragColor;

vec3 CalcDirectionalLight(DirectionalLight light, vec3 normal, vec3 viewDir) {
    vec3 lightDir = normalize(-light.direction);
    float diff = max(dot(normal, lightDir), 0.0);
    
    vec3 reflectDir = reflect(-lightDir, normal);
    float spec = pow(max(dot(viewDir, reflectDir), 0.0), 32);

    vec3 ambient = light.ambient;
    vec3 diffuse = light.diffuse * diff;
    vec3 specular = light.specular * spec;
    
    return (ambient + diffuse + specular);
}

vec3 CalcPointLight(PointLight light, vec3 normal, vec3 viewDir) {
    vec3 lightDir = normalize(light.position - FragPos);
    float diff = max(dot(normal, lightDir), 0.0);
    
    vec3 reflectDir = reflect(-lightDir, normal);
    float spec = pow(max(dot(viewDir, reflectDir), 0.0), 32);

    float distance = length(light.position - FragPos);
    float attenuation = 1.0 / (light.constant + light.linear * distance + light.quadratic * (distance * distance));

    vec3 ambient = light.ambient * attenuation;
    vec3 diffuse = light.diffuse * diff * attenuation;
    vec3 specular = light.specular * spec * attenuation;

    return (ambient + diffuse + specular);
}

vec3 CalcSpotLight(Spotlight light, vec3 normal, vec3 viewDir) {
    vec3 lightDir = normalize(light.position - FragPos);
    float theta = dot(lightDir, normalize(-light.direction));
    
    float epsilon = light.cutOff - light.outerCutOff;
    float intensity = clamp((theta - light.outerCutOff) / epsilon, 0.0, 1.0);

    float diff = max(dot(normal, lightDir), 0.0);
    vec3 reflectDir = reflect(-lightDir, normal);
    float spec = pow(max(dot(viewDir, reflectDir), 0.0), 32);

    vec3 ambient = light.ambient;
    vec3 diffuse = light.diffuse * diff * intensity;
    vec3 specular = light.specular * spec * intensity;

    return (ambient + diffuse + specular);
}

void main() {
    vec3 norm = normalize(Normal);
    vec3 viewDir = normalize(viewPos - FragPos);
    
    vec3 result = CalcDirectionalLight(dirLight, norm, viewDir);
    result += CalcPointLight(pointLight, norm, viewDir);
    result += CalcSpotLight(spotLight, norm, viewDir);

    FragColor = vec4(result, 1.0);
}

1.3. Update Your Main Code

Modify main.cpp to pass light data to the shader.

cpp
shader.use();
shader.setUniform("dirLight.direction", glm::vec3(-0.2f, -1.0f, -0.3f));
shader.setUniform("dirLight.ambient", glm::vec3(0.3f));
shader.setUniform("dirLight.diffuse", glm::vec3(0.7f));
shader.setUniform("dirLight.specular", glm::vec3(1.0f));

shader.setUniform("pointLight.position", lightPos);
shader.setUniform("pointLight.ambient", glm::vec3(0.2f));
shader.setUniform("pointLight.diffuse", glm::vec3(0.8f));
shader.setUniform("pointLight.specular", glm::vec3(1.0f));
shader.setUniform("pointLight.constant", 1.0f);
shader.setUniform("pointLight.linear", 0.09f);
shader.setUniform("pointLight.quadratic", 0.032f);

1️⃣ Shadows (Depth Mapping)

We'll use a shadow map (depth texture) to check whether a fragment is in shadow.

✅ Steps:

  1. Render scene from the light’s perspective → Store depth in a shadow map
  2. Render normal scene → Compare depth with shadow map

1.1. Create a Depth Map

We need an FBO (Frame Buffer Object) and a depth texture.

cpp
unsigned int depthMapFBO;
glGenFramebuffers(1, &depthMapFBO);

unsigned int depthMap;
glGenTextures(1, &depthMap);
glBindTexture(GL_TEXTURE_2D, depthMap);
glTexImage2D(GL_TEXTURE_2D, 0, GL_DEPTH_COMPONENT, 1024, 1024, 0, GL_DEPTH_COMPONENT, GL_FLOAT, NULL);
glTexParameteri(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_MIN_FILTER, GL_NEAREST);
glTexParameteri(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_MAG_FILTER, GL_NEAREST);
glTexParameteri(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_S, GL_CLAMP_TO_BORDER);
glTexParameteri(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_WRAP_T, GL_CLAMP_TO_BORDER);

float borderColor[] = {1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 1.0};
glTexParameterfv(GL_TEXTURE_2D, GL_TEXTURE_BORDER_COLOR, borderColor);

glBindFramebuffer(GL_FRAMEBUFFER, depthMapFBO);
glFramebufferTexture2D(GL_FRAMEBUFFER, GL_DEPTH_ATTACHMENT, GL_TEXTURE_2D, depthMap, 0);
glDrawBuffer(GL_NONE);
glReadBuffer(GL_NONE);
glBindFramebuffer(GL_FRAMEBUFFER, 0);

1.2. Render Depth Map

Create a light-space matrix to render from the light’s POV.

cpp
glm::mat4 lightProjection = glm::ortho(-10.0f, 10.0f, -10.0f, 10.0f, 1.0f, 7.5f);
glm::mat4 lightView = glm::lookAt(lightPos, glm::vec3(0.0f), glm::vec3(0.0f, 1.0f, 0.0f));
glm::mat4 lightSpaceMatrix = lightProjection * lightView;

Pass it to a depth shader:

cpp
depthShader.use();
depthShader.setUniform("lightSpaceMatrix", lightSpaceMatrix);

Render the scene:

cpp
glViewport(0, 0, 1024, 1024);
glBindFramebuffer(GL_FRAMEBUFFER, depthMapFBO);
glClear(GL_DEPTH_BUFFER_BIT);
// Render scene here...
glBindFramebuffer(GL_FRAMEBUFFER, 0);

1.3. Use Shadow Map in the Main Shader

Pass the depth map:

cpp
shader.use();
shader.setUniform("shadowMap", 1);
glActiveTexture(GL_TEXTURE1);
glBindTexture(GL_TEXTURE_2D, depthMap);

Modify the fragment shader:

glsl
float shadowCalculation(vec4 fragPosLightSpace) {
    vec3 projCoords = fragPosLightSpace.xyz / fragPosLightSpace.w;
    projCoords = projCoords * 0.5 + 0.5;
    float closestDepth = texture(shadowMap, projCoords.xy).r;
    float currentDepth = projCoords.z;
    
    float shadow = currentDepth > closestDepth ? 1.0 : 0.0;
    return shadow;
}

Final color:

glsl
vec3 lighting = (1.0 - shadow) * (ambient + diffuse + specular);

2️⃣ PBR (Physically Based Rendering)

PBR uses: ✅ Albedo (Base Color)
✅ Normal Map
✅ Metallic
✅ Roughness
✅ Ambient Occlusion (AO)

2.1. Modify PBR Shader

Use the Cook-Torrance BRDF model.

glsl
#version 330 core
in vec3 FragPos;
in vec3 Normal;

uniform vec3 lightPos;
uniform vec3 lightColor;
uniform vec3 viewPos;

uniform sampler2D albedoMap;
uniform sampler2D metallicMap;
uniform sampler2D roughnessMap;
uniform sampler2D normalMap;
uniform sampler2D aoMap;

out vec4 FragColor;

const float PI = 3.14159265359;

float DistributionGGX(vec3 N, vec3 H, float roughness) {
    float a = roughness * roughness;
    float a2 = a * a;
    float NdotH = max(dot(N, H), 0.0);
    float NdotH2 = NdotH * NdotH;

    float denom = (NdotH2 * (a2 - 1.0) + 1.0);
    denom = PI * denom * denom;

    return a2 / denom;
}

float GeometrySchlickGGX(float NdotV, float roughness) {
    float r = roughness + 1.0;
    float k = (r * r) / 8.0;
    return NdotV / (NdotV * (1.0 - k) + k);
}

float GeometrySmith(vec3 N, vec3 V, vec3 L, float roughness) {
    float NdotV = max(dot(N, V), 0.0);
    float NdotL = max(dot(N, L), 0.0);
    float ggx1 = GeometrySchlickGGX(NdotV, roughness);
    float ggx2 = GeometrySchlickGGX(NdotL, roughness);
    return ggx1 * ggx2;
}

vec3 FresnelSchlick(float cosTheta, vec3 F0) {
    return F0 + (1.0 - F0) * pow(1.0 - cosTheta, 5.0);
}

void main() {
    vec3 albedo = texture(albedoMap, TexCoords).rgb;
    float metallic = texture(metallicMap, TexCoords).r;
    float roughness = texture(roughnessMap, TexCoords).r;
    float ao = texture(aoMap, TexCoords).r;

    vec3 N = normalize(Normal);
    vec3 V = normalize(viewPos - FragPos);

    vec3 F0 = vec3(0.04);
    F0 = mix(F0, albedo, metallic);

    vec3 L = normalize(lightPos - FragPos);
    vec3 H = normalize(V + L);
    
    float NDF = DistributionGGX(N, H, roughness);
    float G = GeometrySmith(N, V, L, roughness);
    vec3 F = FresnelSchlick(max(dot(H, V), 0.0), F0);

    vec3 nominator = NDF * G * F;
    float denominator = 4.0 * max(dot(N, V), 0.0) * max(dot(N, L), 0.0) + 0.0001;
    vec3 specular = nominator / denominator;

    vec3 kS = F;
    vec3 kD = vec3(1.0) - kS;
    kD *= 1.0 - metallic;

    float NdotL = max(dot(N, L), 0.0);
    vec3 Lo = (kD * albedo / PI + specular) * lightColor * NdotL;

    vec3 ambient = vec3(0.03) * albedo * ao;
    vec3 color = ambient + Lo;

    FragColor = vec4(color, 1.0);
}

Final Summary

✅ Shadows using depth maps
✅ PBR for realistic materials

unsigned int depthCubemap;

Render scene six times from the point light.

cpp
glm::mat4 shadowProj = glm::perspective(glm::radians(90.0f), 1.0f, 0.1f, 25.0f);

std::vector<glm::mat4> shadowTransforms = {
    shadowProj * glm::lookAt(lightPos, lightPos + glm::vec3(1.0, 0.0, 0.0), glm::vec3(0.0, -1.0, 0.0)),
    shadowProj * glm::lookAt(lightPos, lightPos + glm::vec3(-1.0, 0.0, 0.0), glm::vec3(0.0, -1.0, 0.0)),
    shadowProj * glm::lookAt(lightPos, lightPos + glm::vec3(0.0, 1.0, 0.0), glm::vec3(0.0, 0.0, 1.0)),
    shadowProj * glm::lookAt(lightPos, lightPos + glm::vec3(0.0, -1.0, 0.0), glm::vec3(0.0, 0.0, -1.0)),
    shadowProj * glm::lookAt(lightPos, lightPos + glm::vec3(0.0, 0.0, 1.0), glm::vec3(0.0, -1.0, 0.0)),
    shadowProj * glm::lookAt(lightPos, lightPos + glm::vec3(0.0, 0.0, -1.0), glm::vec3(0.0, -1.0, 0.0))
};

float ShadowCalculation(vec3 fragPos) {
    vec3 lightToFrag = fragPos - lightPos;
    float closestDepth = texture(depthMap, lightToFrag).r;
    float currentDepth = length(lightToFrag);
    return (currentDepth > closestDepth) ? 1.0 : 0.0;
}

3️⃣ Bloom Effect ✨

Bloom creates a glow effect on bright objects.

✅ Steps:

  1. Render Bright Areas to a Texture
  2. Blur Texture (Gaussian Blur)
  3. Blend with Original Scene

3.1. Render Bright Areas

Extract only bright pixels.

glsl
vec3 hdrColor = texture(sceneTexture, TexCoords).rgb;
float brightness = dot(hdrColor, vec3(0.2126, 0.7152, 0.0722));
vec3 brightColor = (brightness > 1.0) ? hdrColor : vec3(0.0);

3.2. Blur Bright Areas

Apply a Gaussian blur.

glsl
vec3 Blur(vec2 texOffset) {
    vec3 result = vec3(0.0);
    result += texture(sceneTexture, TexCoords + texOffset).rgb * 0.0625;
    result += texture(sceneTexture, TexCoords - texOffset).rgb * 0.0625;
    return result;
}

3.3. Blend Bloom with Scene

Combine bloom with the original scene.

glsl
vec3 finalColor = hdrColor + bloomTexture;
finalColor = 1.0 - exp(-finalColor * exposure);

1️⃣ Screen Space Reflections (SSR) 🪞

SSR simulates reflections by tracing screen-space rays.

✅ Steps:

  1. Render the scene normally
  2. Trace reflection rays in screen space
  3. Sample the color from the reflection point

1.1. Compute Reflection Ray

In the fragment shader, compute the view-space reflection ray.

glsl
vec3 ViewSpaceReflection(vec3 normal, vec3 viewDir) {
    return reflect(-viewDir, normal);
}

1.2. Ray Marching for Reflections

Trace the ray through the depth buffer.

glsl
vec3 RayMarchSSR(vec3 start, vec3 direction, sampler2D depthMap) {
    for (int i = 0; i < 50; i++) {
        start += direction * 0.1;  // Move along the reflection ray
        float depth = texture(depthMap, start.xy).r;  // Sample depth
        if (depth > start.z)  // If we hit something
            return texture(sceneTexture, start.xy).rgb;
    }
    return vec3(0.0);  // No reflection
}

1.3. Final SSR Fragment Shader

glsl
vec3 ReflectionColor = RayMarchSSR(fragPos, ViewSpaceReflection(normal, viewDir), depthMap);
FragColor = vec4(mix(originalColor, ReflectionColor, 0.5), 1.0);

2️⃣ Volumetric Lighting (God Rays) ☀️

Creates the effect of light shafts passing through objects.

✅ Steps:

  1. Render the scene normally
  2. Render a light source mask
  3. Blur it along the light direction

2.1. Render Light Source Mask

Render a texture where only the light source is visible.

glsl
vec3 lightMask = vec3(0.0);
if (isLightSource)  
    lightMask = vec3(1.0);

2.2. Radial Blur (God Rays Effect)

Blur the light mask along the light direction.

glsl
vec3 GodRays(vec2 uv, vec2 lightPos) {
    vec3 result = vec3(0.0);
    vec2 delta = (lightPos - uv) * 0.02;
    for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
        uv += delta;
        result += texture(lightMaskTexture, uv).rgb * 0.1;
    }
    return result;
}

2.3. Blend with Scene

glsl
vec3 finalColor = originalColor + GodRays(TexCoords, lightScreenPos);

3️⃣ Motion Blur / Depth of Field 📷

Motion blur simulates fast movement, while Depth of Field blurs out-of-focus areas.

✅ Steps:

  1. Compute motion vectors
  2. Blur pixels based on velocity
  3. Blur background based on depth

3.1. Compute Motion Vectors

Calculate previous and current positions.

glsl
vec2 velocity = currentScreenPos - previousScreenPos;

3.2. Apply Motion Blur

Use a weighted average of neighboring pixels.

glsl
vec3 MotionBlur(sampler2D texture, vec2 uv, vec2 velocity) {
    vec3 color = vec3(0.0);
    for (float i = 0.0; i < 5.0; i += 1.0) {
        color += texture(texture, uv - velocity * (i / 5.0)).rgb;
    }
    return color / 5.0;
}

3.3. Apply Depth of Field

Blur pixels based on their distance.

glsl
float blurAmount = smoothstep(focusDepth - 0.1, focusDepth + 0.1, depth);
vec3 DoF = mix(originalColor, blurTexture, blurAmount);

1️⃣ Ambient Occlusion (SSAO) 🕶️

SSAO (Screen Space Ambient Occlusion) adds subtle shadows to contact points for depth.

✅ Steps:

  1. Generate a random kernel of samples.
  2. Sample depth buffer in a small area.
  3. Calculate occlusion factor based on depth differences.

1.1. Generate SSAO Kernel

We create random hemisphere samples in the shader.

cpp
std::vector<glm::vec3> ssaoKernel;
for (unsigned int i = 0; i < 64; ++i) {
    glm::vec3 sample(
        (float(rand()) / RAND_MAX) * 2.0 - 1.0,
        (float(rand()) / RAND_MAX) * 2.0 - 1.0,
        (float(rand()) / RAND_MAX)
    );
    sample = glm::normalize(sample);
    sample *= float(i) / 64.0f;
    ssaoKernel.push_back(sample);
}

Pass it to the SSAO shader:

cpp
for (unsigned int i = 0; i < 64; ++i)
    shader.setUniform(("samples[" + std::to_string(i) + "]").c_str(), ssaoKernel[i]);

1.2. SSAO Shader Calculation

Compute occlusion factor based on depth variance.

glsl
float ComputeSSAO(vec3 fragPos, vec3 normal, sampler2D depthMap) {
    float occlusion = 0.0;
    for (int i = 0; i < 64; i++) {
        vec3 samplePos = fragPos + samples[i] * 0.5;
        float sampleDepth = texture(depthMap, samplePos.xy).r;
        occlusion += (sampleDepth < samplePos.z) ? 1.0 : 0.0;
    }
    return 1.0 - (occlusion / 64.0);
}

Final SSAO blending:

glsl
vec3 finalColor = originalColor * ComputeSSAO(fragPos, normal, depthMap);

2️⃣ Lens Flare & Chromatic Aberration 🎥

Lens flares add a cinematic glow, and chromatic aberration simulates real camera distortion.

✅ Steps:

  1. Detect bright areas for lens flare.
  2. Apply radial blur for the streaks.
  3. Distort color channels for chromatic aberration.

2.1. Lens Flare Detection

Extract only the bright pixels.

glsl
vec3 brightColor = (dot(originalColor, vec3(0.2126, 0.7152, 0.0722)) > 1.0) ? originalColor : vec3(0.0);

2.2. Apply Radial Blur

Blur outwards from the light source.

glsl
vec3 ApplyLensFlare(vec2 uv, vec2 lightPos) {
    vec3 result = vec3(0.0);
    vec2 delta = (lightPos - uv) * 0.01;
    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
        uv += delta;
        result += texture(brightTexture, uv).rgb * 0.1;
    }
    return result;
}

2.3. Chromatic Aberration

Offset color channels slightly for a realistic lens effect.

glsl
vec3 ChromaticAberration(vec2 uv, float amount) {
    float r = texture(sceneTexture, uv + vec2(amount, 0.0)).r;
    float g = texture(sceneTexture, uv).g;
    float b = texture(sceneTexture, uv - vec2(amount, 0.0)).b;
    return vec3(r, g, b);
}

Final lens effect blend:

glsl
vec3 finalColor = originalColor + ApplyLensFlare(TexCoords, lightPos);
finalColor = ChromaticAberration(TexCoords, 0.002);

3️⃣ Global Illumination (GI) 🌍

GI simulates realistic indirect lighting by bouncing light off surfaces.

✅ Steps:

  1. Precompute indirect lighting (Voxelization or Light Probes)
  2. Store indirect light in a texture
  3. Use it in the final shading

3.1. Voxelization for GI

We convert the scene into voxels (tiny cubes) to approximate light bounces.

cpp
struct Voxel {
    glm::vec3 color;
    glm::vec3 normal;
};

std::vector<Voxel> voxelGrid(VOLUME_SIZE * VOLUME_SIZE * VOLUME_SIZE);

Render the scene into a voxel grid.

cpp
glm::vec3 voxelPos = (fragPos - sceneMin) / voxelSize;
int index = int(voxelPos.x) + int(voxelPos.y) * VOLUME_SIZE + int(voxelPos.z) * VOLUME_SIZE * VOLUME_SIZE;
voxelGrid[index].color += lightColor * albedo;

3.2. Sample Indirect Light in the Shader

Lookup indirect lighting from the voxel grid.

glsl
vec3 SampleIndirectLighting(vec3 worldPos) {
    vec3 voxelCoord = (worldPos - sceneMin) / voxelSize;
    return texture(voxelTexture, voxelCoord).rgb;
}

Final color:

glsl
vec3 indirectLight = SampleIndirectLighting(fragPos);
vec3 finalColor = directLighting + indirectLight;

✅ Lens Flare & Chromatic Aberration 🎥 – Cinematic camera effects
✅ Global Illumination (GI) 🌍 – Realistic indirect lighting

1️⃣ Ray Traced Reflections (RTR) 🪞

Ray Tracing simulates realistic mirror-like reflections.

✅ Steps:

  1. Cast reflection rays from the surface.
  2. Check for intersections with scene objects.
  3. Fetch reflected color from the hit object.

1.1. Compute Reflection Ray

Calculate ray direction in the fragment shader.

glsl
vec3 ComputeReflection(vec3 viewDir, vec3 normal) {
    return reflect(-viewDir, normal);
}

1.2. Ray Marching for Reflection

We trace the reflection ray to check for intersections.

glsl
vec3 TraceReflection(vec3 rayOrigin, vec3 rayDir) {
    for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
        rayOrigin += rayDir * 0.1;
        float depth = texture(depthMap, rayOrigin.xy).r;
        if (depth > rayOrigin.z)
            return texture(sceneTexture, rayOrigin.xy).rgb;
    }
    return vec3(0.0);  // No reflection
}

1.3. Blend Reflection into Final Color

glsl
vec3 reflectionColor = TraceReflection(fragPos, ComputeReflection(viewDir, normal));
vec3 finalColor = mix(originalColor, reflectionColor, 0.5);

2️⃣ Ray Traced Soft Shadows ☁️

Soft shadows blur at the edges based on light distance.

✅ Steps:

  1. Cast multiple shadow rays
  2. Check occlusion at different offsets
  3. Average results for soft transitions

2.1. Soft Shadow Sampling

Generate multiple random samples.

cpp
std::vector<glm::vec3> softShadowSamples;
for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
    float x = (rand() % 100) / 100.0f;
    float y = (rand() % 100) / 100.0f;
    softShadowSamples.push_back(glm::vec3(x, y, 0));
}

Pass to shader:

cpp
for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
    shader.setUniform(("shadowSamples[" + std::to_string(i) + "]").c_str(), softShadowSamples[i]);
}

2.2. Compute Soft Shadows in Shader

Cast multiple shadow rays.

glsl
float ComputeSoftShadows(vec3 fragPos, vec3 lightPos) {
    float shadow = 0.0;
    for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
        vec3 offset = shadowSamples[i] * 0.1;
        vec3 samplePos = fragPos + offset;
        float depth = texture(depthMap, samplePos.xy).r;
        shadow += (depth < samplePos.z) ? 1.0 : 0.0;
    }
    return 1.0 - (shadow / 16.0);
}

Final shadow blending:

glsl
vec3 finalColor = originalColor * ComputeSoftShadows(fragPos, lightPos);

3️⃣ Real-Time Caustics 💎✨

Caustics are light refractions through water, glass, diamonds, etc.

✅ Steps:

  1. Generate a caustic map
  2. Distort light paths based on surface properties
  3. Project caustics onto nearby surfaces

3.1. Generate Caustic Map

We use Perlin noise to simulate light distortion.

cpp
float PerlinNoise(float x, float y) {
    return fract(sin(dot(glm::vec2(x, y), glm::vec2(12.9898, 78.233))) * 43758.5453);
}

Generate caustic distortion:

cpp
for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
    for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
        causticMap[x][y] = PerlinNoise(x * 0.1, y * 0.1);
    }
}

Pass it to the shader:

cpp
shader.setUniform("causticMap", causticTexture);

3.2. Compute Caustic Effect in Shader

Distort light based on caustic texture.

glsl
vec3 ComputeCaustics(vec3 fragPos, vec3 normal) {
    float distortion = texture(causticMap, fragPos.xy).r;
    vec3 lightColor = vec3(1.0, 0.8, 0.6);
    return lightColor * distortion;
}

Final caustic blending:

glsl
vec3 finalColor = originalColor + ComputeCaustics(fragPos, normal);

1️⃣ Path Tracing (Full GI & Shadows) 🏡

Path tracing simulates realistic global illumination by tracing light rays and bounces.

✅ Steps:

  1. Cast multiple rays from the camera
  2. Simulate light bounces off surfaces
  3. Accumulate results for final shading

1.1. Path Tracing Ray Setup

We shoot multiple rays per pixel for light bounces.

cpp
struct Ray {
    glm::vec3 origin;
    glm::vec3 direction;
};

Generate primary rays:

cpp
Ray GeneratePrimaryRay(int x, int y) {
    glm::vec3 direction = glm::normalize(glm::vec3((x / width) - 0.5, (y / height) - 0.5, -1.0));
    return {cameraPosition, direction};
}

1.2. Light Bouncing Calculation

Simulate ray bounces for indirect lighting.

cpp
glm::vec3 TraceRay(Ray ray, int depth) {
    if (depth > MAX_DEPTH) return glm::vec3(0.0);

    HitInfo hit = SceneIntersect(ray);
    if (!hit.hit) return glm::vec3(0.0);  // No intersection

    Ray newRay;
    newRay.origin = hit.position;
    newRay.direction = glm::reflect(ray.direction, hit.normal);

    return hit.color * TraceRay(newRay, depth + 1);
}

Final shading:

cpp
glm::vec3 color = TraceRay(primaryRay, 0);

2️⃣ Water Simulation (Waves & Foam) 🌊

We use Gerstner Waves for realistic ocean waves and foam.

✅ Steps:

  1. Compute wave displacement using sine waves
  2. Blend multiple waves for realism
  3. Add foam where waves break

2.1. Compute Gerstner Waves

The wave height is a sum of sine functions.

glsl
float ComputeWave(vec2 position, float time) {
    return sin(position.x * 2.0 + time) * 0.1 + 
           sin(position.y * 3.0 + time * 1.5) * 0.05;
}

2.2. Add Foam Effect

Foam appears where waves crest (high curvature).

glsl
float ComputeFoam(float waveHeight) {
    return smoothstep(0.05, 0.1, waveHeight);
}

Final shading:

glsl
vec3 waterColor = mix(vec3(0.0, 0.3, 0.7), vec3(1.0), ComputeFoam(ComputeWave(TexCoords, time)));

glsl
vec3 ComputeSmokeColor(vec3 rayOrigin, vec3 rayDir) {
    float alpha = 0.0;
    vec3 color = vec3(0.0);
    
    for (float t = 0.0; t < maxDist; t += stepSize) {
        vec3 samplePos = rayOrigin + rayDir * t;
        float density = ComputeSmokeDensity(samplePos);
        alpha += density * 0.05;
        color += density * vec3(0.3, 0.3, 0.3);

}

3️⃣ Ray Traced Global Illumination 🌞🔦

Ray Traced GI provides accurate real-time indirect lighting.

✅ Steps:

  1. Trace indirect lighting rays
  2. Accumulate bounce lighting
  3. Use denoising for performance

3.1. Indirect Lighting Ray Tracing

For each fragment, cast rays to sample indirect light.

cpp
vec3 TraceIndirectLight(vec3 origin, vec3 normal) {
    vec3 indirectLight = vec3(0.0);
    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
        vec3 randomDir = SampleHemisphere(normal);
        Ray ray = {origin, randomDir};
        indirectLight += TraceRay(ray, 2);
    }
    return indirectLight / 10.0;
}

3.2. Accumulate Bounce Lighting

Each ray bounce contributes light.

cpp
vec3 AccumulateBounces(Ray ray, int depth) {
    if (depth > MAX_DEPTH) return vec3(0.0);
    HitInfo hit = SceneIntersect(ray);
    if (!hit.hit) return vec3(0.0);

    Ray bounceRay;
    bounceRay.origin = hit.position;
    bounceRay.direction = SampleHemisphere(hit.normal);

    return hit.color * AccumulateBounces(bounceRay, depth + 1);
}

3.3. Denoising for Performance

We use temporal filtering to smooth noise.

cpp
vec3 Denoise(vec3 currentSample, vec3 previousFrame) {
    return mix(previousFrame, currentSample, 0.2);
}

Final indirect lighting:

glsl
vec3 indirectLight = TraceIndirectLight(fragPos, normal);
vec3 finalColor = directLight + indirectLight;

2️⃣ Advanced AI Pathfinding & NPC Behavior 🤖

We implement AI with smart movement, patrols, and combat behavior.

  2. Implement dynamic behavior (patrolling, attacking, hiding)

2.1. A Pathfinding for Smart Movement*

Find the shortest path between NPCs and targets.

cpp
std::vector<Node> AStar(Node start, Node goal) {
    std::priority_queue<Node> openSet;
    openSet.push(start);
    
    while (!openSet.empty()) {
        Node current = openSet.top();
        openSet.pop();
        
        if (current == goal) return ReconstructPath(current);
        
        for (Node neighbor : GetNeighbors(current)) {
            float newCost = current.cost + Distance(current, neighbor);
            if (newCost < neighbor.cost) {
                neighbor.cost = newCost;
                neighbor.parent = current;
                openSet.push(neighbor);
            }
        }
    }
    return {};
}

1️⃣ Real-Time Global Illumination & Ray Traced Shadows 🌞🔦

We implement real-time GI and physically accurate shadows using ray tracing.

✅ Steps:

  1. Use RTX-based or software ray tracing for accurate GI
  2. Sample multiple light bounces for realistic indirect lighting
  3. Denoise and optimize performance

1.1. Ray Traced Shadows

For each pixel, trace a shadow ray towards the light.

cpp
bool IsInShadow(vec3 pos, vec3 lightDir) {
    Ray shadowRay = {pos, lightDir};
    HitInfo hit = SceneIntersect(shadowRay);
    return hit.hit;
}

Use soft shadows by sampling multiple rays:

cpp
float ComputeSoftShadow(vec3 pos, vec3 lightDir) {
    float shadow = 0.0;
    for (int i = 0; i < NUM_SAMPLES; i++) {
        vec3 jitteredDir = lightDir + RandomOffset();
        if (IsInShadow(pos, jitteredDir)) {
            shadow += 1.0;
        }
    }
    return shadow / NUM_SAMPLES;
}

1.2. Real-Time Global Illumination (RTGI)

For indirect lighting, trace rays bouncing off surfaces.

cpp
vec3 ComputeIndirectLight(vec3 origin, vec3 normal) {
    vec3 indirectLight = vec3(0.0);
    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
        vec3 randomDir = SampleHemisphere(normal);
        Ray ray = {origin, randomDir};
        indirectLight += TraceRay(ray, 2);
    }
    return indirectLight / 10.0;
}

1.3. Denoising & Performance Optimization

To reduce noise, apply temporal filtering:

cpp
vec3 Denoise(vec3 currentSample, vec3 previousFrame) {
    return mix(previousFrame, currentSample, 0.2);
}

Final lighting equation:

glsl
vec3 indirectLight = ComputeIndirectLight(fragPos, normal);
vec3 finalColor = directLight + indirectLight;

2️⃣ Dynamic Soft Body Physics & Cloth Simulation 🏗️🧣

We implement real-time deformation for soft bodies and realistic cloth physics.

✅ Steps:

  1. Simulate soft body deformations using spring-mass models
  2. Use verlet integration for stable cloth movement
  3. Optimize with GPU-based physics

2.1. Soft Body Physics

Each object is a network of particles connected by springs.

cpp
struct SoftBody {
    std::vector<Particle> points;
    std::vector<Spring> springs;
};

Update soft body forces and deformations:

cpp
for (auto& spring : softBody.springs) {
    glm::vec3 force = (spring.p1.pos - spring.p2.pos) * stiffness;
    spring.p1.velocity -= force * deltaTime;
    spring.p2.velocity += force * deltaTime;
}

2.2. Cloth Simulation with Verlet Integration

Cloth is a grid of particles connected by constraints.

cpp
struct Cloth {
    std::vector<Particle> nodes;
    std::vector<Constraint> constraints;
};

Verlet integration for stable physics:

cpp
for (auto& p : cloth.nodes) {
    vec3 temp = p.position;
    p.position += (p.position - p.prevPosition) + gravity * deltaTime;
    p.prevPosition = temp;
}

Solve stretching constraints:

cpp
for (auto& constraint : cloth.constraints) {
    glm::vec3 delta = constraint.p1.pos - constraint.p2.pos;
    float diff = (glm::length(delta) - restLength) / glm::length(delta);
    constraint.p1.pos -= delta * diff * 0.5;
    constraint.p2.pos += delta * diff * 0.5;
}

2.3. GPU-Accelerated Cloth Physics

For real-time performance, move physics to the GPU using compute shaders.

glsl
#version 430
layout(local_size_x = 16, local_size_y = 16) in;

void main() {
    uint id = gl_GlobalInvocationID.x;
    positions[id] += velocities[id] * deltaTime;
}

cpp

Clients predict movement before receiving confirmation from the server.

cpp
predictedPosition = currentPosition + velocity * deltaTime;

When the server response arrives, correct the position:

cpp
if (abs(predictedPosition - serverPosition) > threshold) {
    currentPosition = mix(predictedPosition, serverPosition, 0.1);
}

3.3. Synchronizing Game State

The server updates all clients with the latest game state.

cpp
struct GameState {
    std::vector<Player> players;
    std::vector<Object> objects;
};

Clients interpolate to smooth network updates:

cpp
vec3 interpolatedPosition = mix(previousState.position, currentState.position, alpha);

Ensure the character's feet align with terrain slopes.

cpp

IK calculation:

cpp
vec3 SolveIK(vec3 footPosition, vec3 targetPosition, float legLength) {
    vec3 dir = normalize(targetPosition - footPosition);
    return footPosition + dir * legLength;
}

cpp
void ApplyExplosion(vec3 position, float radius) {
    for (int x = -radius; x < radius; x++) {
        for (int y = -radius; y < radius; y++) {
            for (int z = -radius; z < radius; z++) {
                if (length(vec3(x, y, z)) < radius) {
                    terrain.SetVoxel(position + vec3(x, y, z), EMPTY);
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

Break objects into multiple pieces dynamically.

cpp
vector<Mesh> BreakObject(Mesh original, int numPieces) {
    vector<Mesh> pieces;

        pieces.push_back(SplitMesh(original, randomPlane()));
    }
    return pieces;
}

2.3. Real-Time Physics for Debris & Rubble

cpp
for (auto& piece : brokenPieces) {

import tensorflow as tf
import numpy as np

model = tf.keras.models.Sequential([
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(64, activation='relu'),
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(32, activation='relu'),
    tf.keras.layers.Dense(4, activation='softmax')  # Actions: Attack, Defend, Hide, Run
])

def reward_function(action, state):
    if action == "Attack" and state.enemy_health < 20:
        return +10  # Reward for smart attack
    elif action == "Run" and state.health < 10:
        return +5  # Reward for escaping
    return -1  # Small penalty for bad choices

    return "Idle";
}
